title: Opening Remarks at the ICWSM 2011

author: James G. Shanahan, Church and Duncan Group, Inc.

segmentation: Good morning everybody and welcome to the fifth International Triple AI conference on weblogs and social media.
I'm Jimi Shanahan, I'm Co.
Chair of IC WSM 2011 here with my.
The Co chair Nicholas Nikolov.
And we have an exciting educational, educational and entertaining program in store for you over the next few days.
Before we get started, please switch on your mobile devices and tell the world that you're here, and please use the hash sign hash IC WSM, both on Twitter and on Facebook.
As we formally kick off this conference, there are a number of interesting facts about this conference this year.
There are approximately 250 attendees at ICW SM.
This pie chart depicts the distribution of attendees by country, and as you can see, there are a lot of people from North America.
Alot of people from Europe, Asia and South America.
In terms of submissions.
Full paper submissions.
This year was a bumper year at ICW SM.
We had an 80% increase in the number of full paper submissions over last year in previous years.
And if we look out over if we look back over the last three or four years, we can see some steady growth.
And if we squint a little and with a little bit of imagination.
And I know it's very early in a Monday morning to be asking for this.
We can see a hockey stick curve.
And now in the business world, are you excited about that?
I am.
In the business world, and certainly in Silicon Valley, where I hang out and this up into the right curve is a very desirable quality.
Now.
If this trend continues.
The Dow Jones will hit 36,000 points.
But wait a minute, I think today the Dow Jones is at 12,400 points, so we don't have a problem quite yet.
So looking more closely at the accepted papers.
We see papers coming from all over the world.
Asia South America, North America and Europe.
Overall we have a total of 50 three accepted full papers that corresponds to an acceptance rate of 24%.
This year, like previous years, we wanted to keep the conference as a single track.
To maintain this, we added a new track, that of full poster track.
Ann this full post full paper poster track.
We've got two of those sessions both today at 2:15 and tomorrow at 2:15 and we'll talk more about them as they come.
Find it's closer.
In addition, we have.
58 posters and again, this is a distribution according to the origin of these posters.
On the demo front we have 7 demos.
At this point I would like to thank the paper and poster authors.
Along with the demo providers for giving us such a rich, diverse and provocative program.
Please put your hands together and join me in thanking them.
Our organizing committee has been working together on this conference for over 14 months.
And if you can believe it, this is the first time that most of us have been in the same place at the same time.
These ambassadors are here to maximize your experience of ICW SM 2011.
Nicholas Lada Ricardo Scott.
Alex Ricard, Ian Niels day.
Emma Edo John, Ritesh and disco.
Please put your hands together.
Join me in thanking these outstanding organizing committee members.
Sorry, I was off you.
So in addition to this fantastic organizing team, we've had a team of 18.
Senior PC's.
And 105 PC members.
Again, please put your hands together and join me in thanking them.
We have a large staff of student volunteers who are supporting this conference.
Student volunteers if you're here.
Please stand so we can recognize you in the dark, yes.
Student volunteers any takers?
Thank you.
Oh sorry little pump.
OK, without the generous support.
Of our sponsors, this conference would never have gotten off the ground.

At the gold level we give thanks to Google and being at the silver level, we have Yahoo Research and then we have general sponsors in terms of the School of information from the University of Michigan, videolectures.net and the Church and Duncan Group Incorporated.
Triple AI has been a staunch supporter of ICW stem from the start.
And without the tireless efforts of Kareena Anan Carol Carol, we would never gotten here.
So thank you very much for helping us to make this happen.
Video lectures is going to record authorized videos of talks in this conference.
These recordings will be made available online after the conference.
I'm sorry.
And this year we are very fortunate to have been able to grant 29 travel awards to students.
In addition, we had two joint I see WSM 11, Google Eastern European Travel Grant Awards.
That we were able to offer attendees.
Carol, Karina and I truly headed this effort, and I think this is a very important program for our students, so please put your hands together and thank them.
And thank our sponsors for making this happen.
So I want to change gears at this point and solicit some input from you.
In short, what a fantastic year it has been for social media.
It has really come of age over the past 12 to 15 months.
And I would like with your help at this point to get some input.
So can I ask you to take a moment?
And during this moment, turn to a neighbor, preferably somebody you don't know.
And.
Talk about a highlight or a transformational event in social media via technology.
Be it social cultural.
So please take a moment and turn to your neighbors and I may call upon you to tell me what you talked about.
So you got a minute starting now.
Did.
Just in case you didn't hear me.
Well, it seems like there are potentially a wide variety of views about these past 12 months and I would like to share with you some of my thoughts and I've summarized these in terms of a top 10.
Alright so top 10.
Social media is is changing business and society in several ways and in the Old World, information flowed from top to bottom.
But with the advent of social media, information flows from the grassroots back in the.
1930s Dale Carnegie said it best in how to win friends and influence people.
In short, the key to success is to listen 1st and speak later.
And this is definitely a mantra that bears out well in social media.
So this slide is based on a recent report by McKinsey.
There are three big numbers on this slide for you to take home.
First up, there are 5 billion mobile phones in use worldwide.
This is creating.
At 24/7 tethered world.
Which presents huge opportunities an raises some big issues, least of all of which is privacy.
Second up is the 30 billion number.
Can you believe it?
30 billion pieces of content are shared on Facebook every month.
This is on a comparative scale to regular search engines where the typical active index is about 30 billion documents.
This happens every month for Facebook.
Second or third number.
I want you to walk away with is.
All of the world's music can be stored on a hard drive, which costs about $600.
But given what happened yesterday with the ICW SM CD ROM, we have an additional two big soundtracks, so we may require a bigger hard drive.
This is an example of an amazing piece of marketing by Volkswagen.
More people saw this ad on YouTube than actually during the Super Bowl who was aired in February of this year.
If you think of Facebook as a country, it will be the third largest country in the world.
Not bad.
For a company that's been around for seven years.
And this is the penetration of social.
It's in the world with Facebook having a commanding position.
And even the Pope has gotten into social media in 2010 when he set up a Twitter account.
Social media is changing politics dramatically with Barack Obama fielding questions.
From the Speaker of the House via Twitter.
This is a tweet from John Boehner about two weeks ago.
As I alluded to earlier, social media is being transformational on the business front also.
And we can see this first hand in terms of advertising spent.
This year, 4 billion dollars will be spent on advertising and social media.
With Facebook taking over 50% of this.
And Speaking of branding.
Gap launched a new logo last October.
And within 24 hours they choose they chose to revert back to the original logo of 40 years due to very vocal feedback on Twitter and Facebook.
Because of social media, brands are being managed by the masses and not by the trend brand manager.
This has been an investor's year in the sense that many companies in social media has have had valuations that have skyrocketed.
Take for example Twitter 7 billion, 7 billion dollar valuation.
Not to mention Facebook at 100 billion dollars.
Renren, Chinese social media network.
IPO did very successfully in April of this year.
Grew.
Upon
Zynga sorry Zynga.
But this year has also has not been out without its challenges.
Think of my Myspace which crashed and was sold for sale value of $35,000,000.
In addition, during May of this year, Facebook saw 6 million users leave their network.
In North America alone, it's about 4% drop.

Security violating copyrights, violating individual privacy by creating the website www.facemash.com were also charged with being in violation of University policy on distribution of digitized images.
Before we begin with our questioning, it allowed to make a statement.
Would you like to do so?
I.
You know, I've already apologized in the Crimson to the ABH W2 phrasal Latina, and to any women at Harvard who may have been insulted that they take it that they were.
As for any charges stemming from the breach of security, I believe I deserve some recognition from this board.
Yes, I don't understand which part.
What a socially awkward moment, but what a fantastic movie.
It was a huge box office hit.
Around the world, and certainly from a technology perspective, it's an inspiration to any budding engineers and scientists.
One of the most useful apps to come out in the past year is run p.com.
I'm not sure how many of you are familiar with this app, but.
The purpose of this app is to tell you when is the best time during a movie to go have a pee.
Believe it or not, and these times are crowd sourced.
So for example The King's Speech, it's a super long movie and minutes 44.
When the Queen says Long live, the King is literally time to leave and have a pee for five minutes.
But please don't get up from your seats as it's not a break.
It's not time for a break for us yet, so let's just.
Indulge for a moment.
King please don't leave yet.
Alright, I feel we have a fantastic program for ICW SM 2011, so I'm pretty confident as is Nicholas that we won't be needing run P during this conference.
So please loop.
Correct?
OK, one of the biggest and most recent developments in the social media world was the introduction of Google Plus.
It just got interesting for users of social media.
Google Plus is playing in the backyard of Facebook and by doing so it's raising the bar by integrating voice video.
Taking care of privacy issues, dealing with weak and strong ties and overall what a fantastic effort.
So that's my #2 in my top 10 list.
Are you ready for #1?
OK, I don't know if you know Malcolm Gladwell, he's the author of Outliers and the tipping point.
So back in October of last year, he wrote a very controversial article.
One of the main points of the article was that social media.
Could not enable a revolution.
So.
In April of this year, Fareed Zakaria, of CNN interviewed Malcolm.
And Malcolm was unrelenting.
Just after the Arab Spring in in terms of saying social media could not enable a revolution.
Since the spotlight has been put on the MENA region back in December of 2010. Who would have thought the?
Self immolation of Mohammed Bouazizi.
Would have sparked so much change.
Where I got home safely, Monroe.
Except.
Retreat.
I see.
Patient that's Tunisia.
Next up is.
Was online if there is no social network.
Does this does this revolution happen?
If there was no social networks, it would have never been sparked because the whole thing before the revolution was the most critical thing.
Without Facebook, without Twitter, without Google, without YouTube, this would have never happened.
What are your thoughts?
I guess we'll hear about them over the course of the week.
Many of the organizers the social media revolution is not just limited to the MENA region.
It also spread to Italy in the last month when social media overthrew Berlusconi's monopoly of the media in the 4C or force 4S referendum.
Will we ever understand what's happening in the MENA region or throughout the world?
I was just was just happened in the past 12 months.
I think that we have a good chance using relatively simple theories such as herding, population based, cascades, network effects, diffusion models and networks.
Collective action and pluralistic ignorance.
That combined with just lots of data, all your tweets, all your micro messaging.
Will hopefully shed some light on what just happened and to avoid this happening again.
So what does the future hold for us?
Well, I think that the technical program for ICW SM 2011 will provide some key insights with papers and posters addressing some of the.
The following issues.
As I mentioned previously, we've got a fantastic lineup for this week.
This program can be best summarized using.
A tag cloud, so here's the tag cloud for ICW M 2011.
So without further ado, I now declare this conference open and ready for business.
Welcome and have a great conference.
